title: The Windsor Chair's Secret Strength
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Windsor Chair's Secret Strength.

hook.text: The Windsor chair uses four different types of wood in one piece. Each wood is chosen for a specific structural job.

buildup.text: Elm for the seat (resists splitting), ash for the bent back (flexible), beech for the legs (hard), and yew for the bow.

discovery.text: Green (freshly cut) wood was steamed and bent into curves, then dried into permanent shapes without breaking.

twist.text: As the green legs dry, they shrink and grip the seat holes tighterâ€”the joint literally tightens itself over time.

climax.text: Cheap enough for pubs, elegant enough for palacesâ€”the Windsor chair has been continuously made since the 1700s.

punchline.text: Four woods, zero screws, centuries of sitting.

quiz.question: How do Windsor chair joints tighten over time?
options: Green wood legs shrink as they dry, gripping the seat holes
Glue expands with humidity to fill gaps
Metal pins corrode and lock into the wood
